S2.T1.caption: Table 1: The types and names of the four correlation functions we use in this work, along with the tracers used in each of them. Here, we use "flux" to refer to the transmitted flux fraction. The Lyα𝛼\alpha and Lyβ𝛽\beta regions are defined by the rest-frame intervals λRF∈[104,120]subscript𝜆RF104120\lambda_{\mathrm{RF}}\in[104,120]\;nm (situated between the Lyα𝛼\alpha and Lyβ𝛽\beta peaks) and λRF∈[92,102]subscript𝜆RF92102\lambda_{\mathrm{RF}}\in[92,102]\;nm (situated blueward of the Lyβ𝛽\beta peak), respectively.
S2.T1.table:
Type Name Tracer 1 Tracer 2
Auto Lyα𝛼\alpha(Lyα𝛼\alpha)×\timesLyα𝛼\alpha(Lyα𝛼\alpha) Lyα𝛼\alpha flux in the Lyα𝛼\alpha region Lyα𝛼\alpha flux in the Lyα𝛼\alpha region
Lyα𝛼\alpha(Lyα𝛼\alpha)×\timesLyα𝛼\alpha(Lyβ𝛽\beta) Lyα𝛼\alpha flux in the Lyα𝛼\alpha region Lyα𝛼\alpha flux in the Lyβ𝛽\beta region
Cross Lyα𝛼\alpha(Lyα𝛼\alpha)×\timesQSO Lyα𝛼\alpha flux in the Lyα𝛼\alpha region Quasars
Lyα𝛼\alpha(Lyβ𝛽\beta)×\timesQSO Lyα𝛼\alpha flux in the Lyβ𝛽\beta region Quasars
references:
Four types of correlation functions were computed by du Mas des
Bourboux et al. (2020) for the eBOSS DR16 Lyα𝛼\alpha BAO analysis. The first two are the auto-correlation of the Lyα𝛼\alpha flux in the Lyα𝛼\alpha region, Lyα𝛼\alpha(Lyα𝛼\alpha)×\timesLyα𝛼\alpha(Lyα𝛼\alpha), and its cross-correlation with Lyα𝛼\alpha flux in the Lyβ𝛽\beta region, Lyα𝛼\alpha(Lyα𝛼\alpha)×\timesLyα𝛼\alpha(Lyβ𝛽\beta). The other two are cross-correlations between Lyα𝛼\alpha forest flux and quasars, and include the cross-correlation of quasars with Lyα𝛼\alpha flux in the Lyα𝛼\alpha region: Lyα𝛼\alpha(Lyα𝛼\alpha)×\timesQSO, and with Lyα𝛼\alpha flux in the Lyβ𝛽\beta region: Lyα𝛼\alpha(Lyβ𝛽\beta)×\timesQSO. The Lyα𝛼\alpha region is found between the Lyα𝛼\alpha and Lyβ𝛽\beta peaks, and is defined by the rest-frame interval λRF∈[104,120]subscript𝜆RF104120\lambda_{\mathrm{RF}}\in[104,120]\;nm. The Lyβ𝛽\beta region is blueward of the Lyβ𝛽\beta peak, and is defined by the rest-frame interval λRF∈[92,102]subscript𝜆RF92102\lambda_{\mathrm{RF}}\in[92,102]\;nm. This information is summarized in Table 1.

S2.T2.caption: Table 2: The two types of analysis we perform in this work, along with the scale parameters we measure in each of them and their description.
S2.T2.table:
Analysis type Parameters Description Cosmological Information
Split AP measurement ϕpsubscriptitalic-ϕp\phi_{\mathrm{p}} Peak anisotropy AP from BAO
ϕssubscriptitalic-ϕs\phi_{\mathrm{s}} Broadband anisotropy AP from broadband
αpsubscript𝛼p\alpha_{\mathrm{p}} Peak isotropic scale BAO scale
αssubscript𝛼s\alpha_{\mathrm{s}} Broadband isotropic scale Marginalized out
Full AP measurement ϕfsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑓\phi_{f} Full-shape anisotropy AP from full correlation
αpsubscript𝛼p\alpha_{\mathrm{p}} Peak isotropic scale BAO scale
αssubscript𝛼s\alpha_{\mathrm{s}} Broadband isotropic scale Marginalized out
references: The two main types of analyses we will perform are described in Table 2. In the first one, which we will refer to as the "split AP measurement", we fit two distinct ϕitalic-ϕ\phi parameters for the peak and smooth components separately. In the second one, called "full AP measurement", we fit one ϕitalic-ϕ\phi parameter to the full shape of the correlations. When performing this analysis on real data, we want to use the full AP measurement, because it coherently extracts the desired information. The split AP measurement can be used as a consistency check of the method or data. However, it is also useful in the current work, because ϕssubscriptitalic-ϕs\phi_{\mathrm{s}} quantifies the gain in information over a standard BAO-only analysis.

We model the Lyα𝛼\alpha auto-correlation, and its cross-correlation with quasars, using a similar approach to that used in past Lyα𝛼\alpha BAO analyses (Kirkby
et al., 2013; Bautista
et al., 2017; du Mas des
Bourboux et al., 2017, 2020), as described in Section 2.3. The only difference appears from the fact that we use scale parameters to fit the full shapes of the correlations. Our parametrization of the scale parameters splits them into an isotropic scale parameter, α𝛼\alpha, and a parameter for the anisotropy, ϕitalic-ϕ\phi, corresponding to a measurement of the AP effect (Cuceu et al., 2021). As we decompose the template power spectrum into a peak component and a smooth component, we have the option of using separate scale parameters for each. We use two setups for the analysis, as described in Table 2. In the first, we decouple the peak and smooth components by fitting two distinct ϕitalic-ϕ\phi parameters (ϕpsubscriptitalic-ϕp\phi_{\mathrm{p}} and ϕssubscriptitalic-ϕs\phi_{\mathrm{s}}), while in the second we fit only one ϕitalic-ϕ\phi parameter (ϕfsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑓\phi_{f}) for the full shapes of the correlations.

S2.T3.caption: Table 3: List of the free parameters in our model, along with their description and priors. U​(min,max)𝑈min,maxU(\text{min,max}) represents a flat prior within that interval, while 𝒩​(μ,σ2)𝒩𝜇superscript𝜎2\mathcal{N}(\mu,\sigma^{2}) represents a Gaussian prior.

references: In Table 3, we give a description of all the free parameters in our standard analysis, along with their priors. We follow past BAO analyses, and assign a Gaussian prior to the RSD parameter of HCDs, based on measurements of DLA clustering (Pérez-Ràfols et al., 2018).
